properties.Name: PartyPsychographicCriteria

Columns.Name: PartyId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Party.

Columns.Name: PsychographicCriteriaId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Psychographic Criteria.

Columns.Name: PeriodStartDate
Columns.Description: The period start date for which the associated data is effective or 'as-of'.

Columns.Name: PeriodEndDate
Columns.Description: The period end date for which the associated data is effective or 'as-of'.

Columns.Name: PartyPsychographicCriteriaNote
Columns.Description: A note, comment or additional information related to Party Psychographic Criteria.

Properties.DerivedModelEntityInfo:
{"entityDirectives":{"baseEntityReference":{"name":"PartyPsychographicCriteria","path":"PartyPsychographicCriteria.cdm.json/PartyPsychographicCriteria"},"description":"The one or more psychographic criteria that are assigned or linked to an Individual and by which they are identified or qualified from a psychographic focus.

These criteria can change over a period of time and are represented with 'period start date/period end date' qualifications, which represented the best case for knowing this information.    If the data is only randomly sampled or recorded then you could use a single 'date' to identify its recording or effective as-of date.

Demographics are the average or typical characteristics of the people who buy your products or services. They include age, income, education, status or type of occupation, region of country and household size. Demographics can also include the age of children, home ownership, home value and urban or rural location. 

Psychographics take demographics further by addressing people's lifestyles and behaviors - their values, interests and what they do - their 'lifestyles'.
Psychographic Segmentation is market segmentation defined in terms of psychographics.   

This type of segmentation is frequently used because of the strong relationship between activities, interests and opinions and products or services purchased.    

Lifestyle groups are typically defined in terms of its member activities, interests and opinions.  Consumption patterns relate to when, why, where, and how consumers purchase or acquire goods or services.

The Psychographic Criteria is the specific criteria or value that will be linked to a Market Segment.   

The following are examples:

Psychographic Criteria:  Middle Class
Psychographic Criteria Type:  Social Class

Psychographic Criteria:  Young, Upwardly-mobile, Professional 
Psychographic Criteria Type: Lifestyle

Psychographic Criteria:  Conservative
Psychographic Criteria Type:  Political Philosophy

Example:

Thus a Market Segment "Middle Class, Young, Upwardly-mobile, Professional, Conservative" could select the following Psychographic Criteria for its composition:

Psychographic Criteria:  Middle Class
Psychographic Criteria Type:  Social Class

Psychographic Criteria:  Young, Upwardly-mobile, Professional 
Psychographic Criteria Type: Lifestyle

Psychographic Criteria:  Conservative
Psychographic Criteria Type:  Political Philosophy

Properties.Description:
The one or more psychographic criteria that are assigned or linked to an Individual and by which they are identified or qualified from a psychographic focus.

These criteria can change over a period of time and are represented with 'period start date/period end date' qualifications, which represented the best case for knowing this information.    If the data is only randomly sampled or recorded then you could use a single 'date' to identify its recording or effective as-of date.

Demographics are the average or typical characteristics of the people who buy your products or services. They include age, income, education, status or type of occupation, region of country and household size. Demographics can also include the age of children, home ownership, home value and urban or rural location. 

Psychographics take demographics further by addressing people's lifestyles and behaviors - their values, interests and what they do - their 'lifestyles'.
Psychographic Segmentation is market segmentation defined in terms of psychographics.   

This type of segmentation is frequently used because of the strong relationship between activities, interests and opinions and products or services purchased.    

Lifestyle groups are typically defined in terms of its member activities, interests and opinions.  Consumption patterns relate to when, why, where, and how consumers purchase or acquire goods or services.

The Psychographic Criteria is the specific criteria or value that will be linked to a Market Segment.   

The following are examples:

Psychographic Criteria:  Middle Class
Psychographic Criteria Type:  Social Class

Psychographic Criteria:  Young, Upwardly-mobile, Professional 
Psychographic Criteria Type: Lifestyle

Psychographic Criteria:  Conservative
Psychographic Criteria Type:  Political Philosophy

Example:

Thus a Market Segment "Middle Class, Young, Upwardly-mobile, Professional, Conservative" could select the following Psychographic Criteria for its composition:

Psychographic Criteria:  Middle Class
Psychographic Criteria Type:  Social Class

Psychographic Criteria:  Young, Upwardly-mobile, Professional 
Psychographic Criteria Type: Lifestyle

Psychographic Criteria:  Conservative
Psychographic Criteria Type:  Political Philosophy

The psychographic characteristics of a market influence the 'marketing mix' strategy components introduced to that market and sales channels used to provide products to that market.
